Problem:
Consider a function \( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \) where \( x(t) \) and \( y(t) \) are solutions to the differential equations \( \dot{x} = Ax \) and \( \dot{y} = By \) respectively, with A and B being constant matrices. We analyze the impact of a Fourier transform on \( z(t) \), defined by \( \mathcal{F}\{z\}(s) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-ist}z(t) dt \).

If \( \mathcal{F}\{z\}(s) \) is calculated without any modification to \( z(t) \), will the outcome at frequency \( s \) be solely dependent on the properties of matrices A and B?
Explanation: The Fourier transform of \( z(t) \) captures the frequency components inherent to the functions \( x(t) \) and \( y(t) \), which are solely governed by matrices A and B respectively. The outcome at any specific frequency \( s \) in \( \mathcal{F}\{z\}(s) \) will directly reflect the characteristics of A and B as long as no modifications or interventions are applied to \( z(t) \).
